title: Second next greater element
problem_statement:
Second next greater element

Problem Description

You are given an array A of size N and an integer X.

For each element, Aᵢ, find the value of the second next greater element by X to the right.

Notes:

  • Nested indexing is followed:
  • Second next greater element by X for any element Aᵢ is defined as the value of the element Aⱼ (i < j) such that A[i] + X < A[j] and there exists exactly one index k such that A[i] + X < A[k] where (i < k < j).

Complete the function solve. This function takes the following 3 parameters and returns an array of N integers where iᵗʰ integer is denoting the value of the second next greater element by X to the right of A[i].

Parameters:

  • N: Represents an integer denoting the size of array A
  • X: Represents an integer denoting X
  • A: Represents an integer array denoting A

Input format for custom testing

Note: Use this input format if you are testing against custom input or writing code in a language where we don't provide boilerplate code.

  • The first line contains two space-separated integers, N and X.
  • The next line contains N space-separated elements denoting the elements of array A.

Output format

Print N space-separated integers representing the required answer for each index.

Print -1 if no such element exists.

Examples

Example 1:

Input:
7 2
1 2 3 4 7 6 7
Output:
4 7 6 6 -1 -1 -1

Explanation:

Given

  • N = 7
  • X = 2
  • A = [1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 6, 7]

Approach:

  • For A₀, the elements greater than A₀ + 2 = 3 to the right are 3 and 4. The second next greater element is 4.
  • For A₁, the elements greater than A₁ + 2 = 4 to the right are 4 and 7. The second next greater element is 7.
  • For A₂, the elements greater than A₂ + 2 = 5 to the right are 7 and 6. The second next greater element is 6.
  • For A₃, the elements greater than A₃ + 2 = 6 to the right are 7 and 6. The second next greater element is 6.
  • For A₄, there are no elements greater than A₄ + 2 = 9 to the right. Thus the answer is -1.
  • For A₅, there are no elements greater than A₅ + 2 = 8 to the right. Thus the answer is -1.
  • For A₆, there are no elements greater than A₆ + 2 = 9 to the right. Thus the answer is -1.

Therefore the answer is [4, 7, 6, 6, -1, -1, -1]

Constraints

  • 1 <= N <= 10^5
  • 1 <= A[i] <= 10^9
  • 1 <= X <= 10^9

title: Team's average players
problem_statement:
```html

Team's average players

Problem Description

In a Baseball tournament, each player's score was recorded. The player who scored the maximum runs in their team is considered the team leader. Players in the team who scored greater than or equal to 50% of the leader's score are categorized as the average players of the team.

For example, if the team leader has scored 100 runs, then the player with a score greater than or equal to 50 would be an average player of that team.

You are given tables from the database baseball_tournament.

Task: Write a query to find the count of average players in a team. Arrange the answer in the order of team name. (A-Z)

Input Format:

Table: p_score

Name    Type    Description
p_id    int     Represents the unique id of the player
t_id    int     Represents the id of the player's team
score   int     Represents the score of the player

Table: t_details

Name      Type      Description
t_id      int       Represents the unique id of the team
t_name    varchar   Represents the name of the team

Output Format:

Name              Type    Description
t_name            varchar Represents the name of the team
avg_players_count int     Represents the number of average players in each team

Examples

Example 1:

Input tables:

Table: p_score

p_id | t_id | score
-----|------|------
1    | 21   | 67
2    | 23   | 87
3    | 25   | 92
4    | 23   | 104
5    | 22   | 88
6    | 21   | 176
7    | 24   | 126
8    | 22   | 160
9    | 23   | 155
10   | 21   | 122
11   | 21   | 101
12   | 22   | 198
13   | 26   | 156
14   | 26   | 89
15   | 21   | 76
16   | 26   | 144
17   | 25   | 167
18   | 26   | 152
19   | 27   | 166
20   | 28   | 88
21   | 29   | 132
22   | 30   | 187

Table: t_details

team_id | team_name
--------|-----------
21      | Blue bulls
22      | Englishmen
23      | Yankees
24      | Philadelphia
25      | Atlanta
26      | Toronto Blue

Output table:

t_name       | avg_players_count
-------------|------------------
Atlanta      | 2
Blue bulls   | 5
Englishmen   | 1
Philadelphia | 3
Toronto Blue | 4
Yankees      | 3

Constraints

Note: Your SQL query must be able to print the sample output from the provided sample input. However, the query is run against multiple hidden test cases. Therefore, your query must pass these hidden test cases to solve the problem statement.

Limits:

  • Time Limit: 5 sec(s) for each input file
  • Memory Limit: 256 MB
  • Source Limit: 1024 KB

Scoring: Score is assigned if any testcase passes

Allowed Languages: MySQL, PostgreSQL, MSSQL, Oracle_Db

```
